doc.title: Alibaba Q1: A transformational quarter
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Alibaba Q1 A transformational quarterAlibaba Q1 A transformational quarter_2025-08-29

passages.text: **Alibaba Group Holding Ltd**

**The house that Jack built. Alibaba's Q1 print was expected to be about food delivery** losses, and CMR comps that get tougher from September. While food delivery spend did drive a Q1 EBITA miss, this was quickly forgotten after an analyst call for the history books.Management pointed to 300mn monthly quick commerce customers, a tripling to over 2mn of daily active riders, 80mn daily orders, and 20% growth in Taobao DAUs. The plan from here: leverage food delivery, quick commerce, and AI to drive engagement and cross-selling across Alibaba's vast ecosystem.

**It's only "irrational" if you're losing.** For a company not always known for guiding concisely, today felt like directional change. While July and August saw huge spend on user and rider acquisition, Alibaba pointed to expectations that food delivery unit losses can halve by October... meaning Q2 will be the peak investment quarter. CMR growth was guided to remain close to this quarter's 10% print, with cross-selling contributing 2-3% growth.Alibaba argued that quick commerce can add RMB1tn of incremental GMV by FY3/28.

**AI AI AI AI AI.** Alicloud revenue grew 25.8% year on year in Q1, up versus +17.7% in Q4. For the first time, Alibaba noted that AI-related revenues contributed over 20% of external Cloud revenues (c. 75-80% of reported). RMB3.0bn of Cloud EBITA in Q1 implied an 8.8% EBITA margin, similar to Q4. Management speaking on the calls pointed to the RMB38.7bn of capex this quarter as evidence they were seeing strong inference and training demand, and pointed to expectations for continued revenue acceleration in the coming quarters.

**The Q1 numbers... for what it's worth.** Q1 group revenue of RMB248bn compared with consensus on RMB253bn. RMB38.8bn of group adjusted EBITA missed consensus on RMB43.2bn. CMR grew10.1% year on year to RMB89.3bn. Assuming 80% drop-down margin on this would imply something like a RMB15bn year on year increase in food delivery investments, all else equal. According to Alibaba management, China E-commerce EBITA rose year on year, excluding the impact of food delivery spend.
We rate Alibaba Outperform (PT US$160/HK$156).

Alibaba's Q1 result was mediocre, but at the time of writing has already been consigned to irrelevance, on the back of a game- changing analyst call.

Group revenue of RMB248bn in the June quarter was \(1.8\%\) higher year on year, weighed down by the Sun Art disposal, while RMB38.8bn of group adjusted EBITA was \(13.7\%\) lower year on year. \(10.1\%\) CMR growth to RMB89.3bn compared with our estimate on RMB88.7bn, and consensus on RMB87.3bn. The newly formed China E- commerce Group saw revenue of RMB140bn, \(9.7\%\) higher year on year, while RMB38.4bn of segment EBITA was \(21.3\%\) lower. Assuming \(80\%\) drop- down margins on CMR would imply RMB16bn of negative delta year on year. We think it's safe to assume a large part of this related to Alibaba's food delivery spend this quarter.

RMB33.4bn of Cloud revenue was \(25.8\%\) higher year on year. The latter was up versus \(17.7\%\) growth in Q4. RMB3.0bn of Alicloud EBITA this quarter implied a \(9.0\%\) incremental EBITA margin year on year. Adding back the group level delta in depreciation & amortization costs to Cloud EBITA this year and last implies a lower incremental cloud EBITDA margin than last quarter (in the \(40\%\) range), though this analysis is likely significantly distorted by the Sun Art disposal this quarter. More importantly, management speaking around the quarter pointed to RMB38.7bn of capex this quarter as evidence the company was seeing strong training and inference demand, and to further top- line acceleration in the upcoming quarters.

For a company not always known for guiding concisely, this quarter felt like directional change. The plan going forward is clear: leverage food delivery, quick commerce, and AI to drive engagement across the company's vast ecosystem. Losses in the business outside China E- commerce and Cloud reached an aggregate RMB2.5bn this quarter, \(58.7\%\) lower compared with RMB6.1bn in Q1 FY3/25 a year ago. Looking back, our upgrade of Alibaba's shares earlier this year during peak DeepSeek excitement was poorly timed. But our belief at the time - that AI investments would help steer Alibaba towards more gainful capital allocation - now appears to be taking shape.

On food delivery, Alibaba argued its AOV was only \(20\%\) lower than Meituan's after subsidies. Guidance that food delivery unit losses can halve by October was far more constructive than we'd anticipated, and implies Q2 will be the peak quarter for losses (albeit after doubling versus Q1). Alibaba's stated goal to become the leading food delivery and quick commerce player in China will sound ominous to Meituan, two days after the latter failed to give a good account of how it planned to fight back. The evidence from the last few months suggests Alibaba was able to capture substantial food delivery and quick commerce share while only spending moderately more than Meituan.

Alibaba's commentary about its food delivery unit economics stood in sharp contrast with Meituan's commentary on Alibaba earlier in the week. As always, the truth probably lies somewhere in between on key variables like AOV and aggregate unit losses. What's not up for debate in our view is that the network effects in the food delivery business generally correlate positively with order volume scale... and right now Alibaba has the order volume momentum.

Meituan can of course up the ante on spend, to slow Alibaba's progress. We'd argue it needs to do so, lest the perceived problem facnits shares becomes increasingly existential in the minds of investors. Meituan living up to its promise to "do whatever it takes" probably represents the key risk to Alibaba earnings estimates from here. The convergence of e- commerce and food delivery competition still leaves a hyper- competitive market with too many players. But balance sheet strength wins in a fight to the death in this industry, and RMB184bn versus RMB126bn of net cash as of June 2025 argues in Alibaba's favour.
Exhibit 1 to Exhibit 3 show summaries of Alibaba's Q1 earnings.
EXHIBIT 1: Alibaba: Results summary

We've updated our estimates for Alibaba to reflect Q1 FY3/26 reporting, and our discussions with the company around the quarter. On balance, our estimates are higher versus our prior estimates in FY3/27 and FY3/28, though our assumptions for lower buybacks means the per share amounts are actually very modestly lower. Our latest price target for Alibaba reflects our SOTP valuation for Alibaba, valuing e- commerce on 11x FY3/27E PE, and valuing external cloud revenues on 5x PS... and implies 15x headline FY3/27E PE.
Exhibit 4 shows a summary of our estimate changes for Alibaba.

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.
We value Meituan at HK\$95 per share, on a 1.3x 2026E PS multiple.
We value Alibaba at US\$160/HK\$156 per share, on a SOTP valuation valuing e- commerce on 11x FY3/27E PE, Cloud on 5x FY3/27E PS.

The main upside risks associated with significantly reduced competition in the food delivery sector, changes of overseas strategy resulting in lower than expected international losses, and much faster revenue and profit growths for Instashopping.

The main downside risks associated with our price target for Meituan include macroeconomic risks (e.g. credit, retail consumption), fluctuations in user engagement with its platforms, food delivery unit economics - including average order value, monetisation rate, rider costs, and operating expenses, competition with rival internet platforms (e.g. Ele.me, Trip.com), regulatory risks - for example related to China's anti- monopoly regulations, and losses in the company's new businesses (e.g. community e- commerce).

The main downside risks associated with our price target for Alibaba include macroeconomic risks (e.g. credit, retail consumption), fluctuations in user engagement with Taobao, Tmall, and other platforms, competition with rival internet platforms, regulatory risks - for example related to China's anti- monopoly regulations, and losses in the company's innovation initiatives & others segment.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:
- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp
Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+ / - 15\) pp
Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI)index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non-Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:
·Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp
·Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within \(+/-10\) pp
·Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC)denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12-month time horizon.
